intro: Draba handelii, commonly known as the Handel's whitlow grass, is a small flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbages, and is characterized by its simple, basal leaves and small, white or pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine environments, thriving in well-drained soils and cool climates. It is a perennial herb that produces a capsule fruit containing numerous seeds, which are dispersed by wind. Draba handelii is often found in high-altitude areas, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local biodiversity.
